{{about|the gossip magazine||In Touch (disambiguation)}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2008}} {{Infobox Magazine | title = In Touch Weekly | image_file = In Touch Weekly magazine cover.png | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = David Perel | editor_title = Editorial Director | based = [[Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey]] | frequency = Weekly | total_circulation = 595,614<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcas3.auditedmedia.com/ecirc/magtitlesearch.asp |title= eCirc for Consumer Magazines|date= June 30, 2012 |work=Alliance for Audited Media|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> |circulation_year = June 2012 | category = [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|Tabloid]] / [[Gossip magazine|Gossip]] | company = [[American Media, Inc.]] | publisher = | founded = 2002 | country = United States | language = [[English language|English]] | website = {{URL|intouchweekly.com|InTouchWeekly.com}} | issn = 1540-8280 }} '''''In Touch Weekly''''' is an American celebrity [[gossip magazine]]. The magazine is focused on [[celebrities|celebrity]] news, fashion, beauty, relationships and lifestyle, and is geared towards a younger readership, billing itself as "fast and fun", along with making claims about their lower cover price on their front cover to encourage buyers to purchase their magazine rather than the other titles on a supermarket checkout rack.It usually targets younger woman and teenage girls.
==History and profile== The magazine was launched in 2002 by [[Bauer Media Group|Bauer Publishing]];<ref>{{cite news|author=David Carr|title=A Down-Market Publisher Dresses Up|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/25/business/media/25mag.html?_r=0|accessdate=25 July 2015|work=The New York Times|date=25 October 2004}}</ref> Richard Spencer was editor from its launch until 2010. [[American Media, Inc.]] acquired Bauer's US celebrity magazines in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web| title = Bauer Media sells most of US portfolio – 17 titles down to just four| work = Mediaweek| accessdate = 2018-07-29| date = 2018-06-18| url = https://mediaweek.com.au/bauer-media-sells-us-portfolio-ami-2018/}}</ref>
The magazine shares a publisher with its sister magazine ''[[Life & Style Weekly]]'', a similar weekly gossip magazine. Whereas ''In Touch'' is focused more on celebrity gossip, ''Life & Style'' bills itself on giving readers lifestyle tips on how to incorporate celebrity beauty and fashion into their lives.
On September 18, 2006, after the death of [[Daniel Wayne Smith]], son of [[Anna Nicole Smith]], [[Getty Images]] sold the last photos taken of Daniel alive at his mother's bedside to ''In Touch Weekly'' and ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'' for a reported $650,000.
On May 21, 2015, the magazine controversially released a police investigation of [[Josh Duggar]] from the ''[[19 Kids and Counting]]'' reality TV show, from an investigation carried out in 2006, when Josh was 18 years of age, about events occurring in 2002, when Josh was 14 and still a minor, when he was accused of molesting his sisters and several other girls. No charges were ever filed. Although the magazine was criticized for releasing the report, the [[Springdale, Arkansas]] city attorney and several legal experts said that since Josh was 18 at the time of the investigation and all minors' names were redacted, the release was permitted under Arkansas' Freedom of Information Act.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/tv/ct-josh-duggar-record-destroyed-20150522-story.html|title=Judge orders Josh Duggar's record destroyed|work=Chicago Tribune|date=May 22, 2015|accessdate=June 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Release of Josh Duggar's Police Report Raises New Legal Questions|url=http://insider.foxnews.com/2015/06/02/josh-duggars-police-report-release-raises-questions|accessdate=June 4, 2015|work=Fox News|date=2 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Henry|first1=Larry|title=Senator: Springdale Police Chief Should Be Fired Over Child Sex-Crime Report|url=http://5newsonline.com/2015/05/23/senator-springdale-police-chief-should-be-fired-over-child-sex-crime-report/|accessdate=June 4, 2015|publisher=5 News|date=May 24, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Chasner|first1=Jessica|title=Bart Hester, Arkansas lawmaker, wants police chief fired over release of Josh Duggar report|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/may/26/bart-hester-arkansas-lawmaker-wants-police-chief-f/|accessdate=4 June 2015|publisher=The Washington Times|date=May 26, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=City Of Springdale Responds To Josh Duggar Sexual Molestation Accusations|url=http://5newsonline.com/2015/06/04/city-of-springdale-responds-to-josh-duggar-sexual-molestation-accusations/|accessdate=June 5, 2015|work=5 News|date=June 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Helsel|first1=Phil|title=Josh Duggar Molestation Scandal: City Defends Release of Record|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/josh-duggar-scandal-city-defends-release-record-n370171|accessdate=5 June 2015|publisher=NBC News|date=5 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2015/06/05/heres-why-releasing-josh-duggars-records-was-probably-not-illegal|title=Here’s why releasing Josh Duggar’s records was probably not illegal|last=Brittain|first=Amy|work=The Washington Post|date=June 5, 2015}}</ref>
According to the website, as of 2010, ''In Touch Weekly'' sells for $2.99 on newsstands, 50 cents less than competitors ''US Weekly'' and ''Star Magazine''.

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Insidious: Chapter 2 | image = Insidious – Chapter 2 Poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[James Wan]] | producer = {{Plainlist| *[[Jason Blum]] *[[Oren Peli]] }} | screenplay = [[Leigh Whannell]] | story = {{Plainlist| *James Wan *Leigh Whannell }} | based on = <!--- Though the film credits Whannell's characters as it's basis, this is a direct sequel. Including this information is unnecessary ---> | starring = {{Plainlist| *[[Patrick Wilson (American actor)|Patrick Wilson]] *[[Rose Byrne]] *[[Lin Shaye]] *[[Ty Simpkins]] *[[Barbara Hershey]] <!-- per film poster --> }} | music = [[Joseph Bishara]] | editing = Kirk Morri | cinematography = [[John R. Leonetti]] | studio = [[Blumhouse Productions]]<ref name=afi>{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/members//catalog/DetailView.aspx?s=&Movie=69673|title=Insidious: Chapter 2|work=[[American Film Institute]]|accessdate=November 15, 2016}}</ref> | distributor = [[FilmDistrict]]<ref name=afi/> | released = {{Film date|2013|9|13|ref1=<ref name="release" />}} | runtime = 106 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 105:28--><ref>{{cite web|title=''INSIDIOUS - CHAPTER 2'' (15)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/insidious-chapter-2-film|work=[[E1 Films]]|publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=August 19, 2013|accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> | country = United States<ref name=afi/> | language = English | budget = $5 million<ref name="BOM" /> | gross = $161.9 million<ref name="BOM" /> }} '''''Insidious: Chapter 2''''' is a 2013 American [[supernatural horror film]] directed by [[James Wan]]. It is a [[sequel]] to ''[[Insidious (film)|Insidious]],'' the second installment in the [[Insidious (film series)|''Insidious'' franchise]], and the fourth in terms of the series' in-story chronology. The film stars [[Patrick Wilson (American actor)|Patrick Wilson]] and [[Rose Byrne]] reprising their roles as Josh and Renai Lambert, a husband and wife who seek to uncover the secret that has left them dangerously connected to the spirit world.
The film was released September 13, 2013. A [[prequel]] film, ''[[Insidious: Chapter 3]]'', was released on June 5, 2015.
== Plot == In 1986, Lorraine Lambert summons [[demonology|demonologist]] Elise Rainier to help her son Josh, who is being followed by the spirit of an old woman. After investigating the house and encountering [[paranormal|paranormal phenomena]], Elise tells Lorraine that they must suppress Josh's [[astral projection]] abilities for his own safety.
Twenty-five years later, Renai Lambert is under questioning about the [[Insidious (film)|death of Elise]]. She is warned that if her husband Josh's fingerprints are found at the crime scene, he will be prosecuted for Elise's murder. The Lambert family relocate to Lorraine's house as the investigation continues. Renai and the others begin to experience strange, seemingly paranormal activity in the house.
Specs and Tucker visit Elise's house and discover a videotape of the 1986 investigation. Upon reviewing it, they find someone standing behind Josh in the video. The next morning, Dalton tells Renai that he has been having bad dreams involving a woman in a white dress; as well as hearing Josh talk to an unseen figure in the hallway. Renai receives a call from the police stating that the fingerprints do not match Josh. The woman in the white dress appears and attacks Renai. Josh hears a voice urging him to kill his family.
Lorraine visits Specs and Tucker and they show her the tape, enhanced to show an adult Josh as the figure standing behind the young Josh. They contact Elise's former colleague Carl, who attempts to contact Elise's spirit. They are told to find answers at an abandoned hospital where Lorraine used to work as a doctor. Upon arriving, Lorraine recounts the story of a patient named Parker Crane who was admitted for trying to castrate himself. Two days later, Lorraine saw Parker in an elevator. When Lorraine asked a nurse why Parker was out of his bed, the nurse explained that he had [[suicide|jumped to his death from the roof]] the day before.
Lorraine and the group go to the Crane family home where they find a secret room. Inside they discover numerous corpses, a black wedding gown and newspaper clippings revealing Parker to be a killer referred to as "The Bride in Black" - who kidnapped and murdered young women while dressed as a woman himself. Josh's body begins to slowly deteriorate and Renai realizes he is possessed. Lorraine insists that they all get away from Josh. Carl arrives to drug him, accompanied by Specs and Tucker, but Josh manages to subdue all three. Carl awakes in the spirit realm of "The Further", where he meets the spirit of the real Josh. Josh travels to his daughter Cali's room in "The Further", where an evil spirit is approaching her. He struggles with the spirit but is overpowered. Elise's spirit arrives and banishes the spirit from the house. It is revealed that these actions are what triggered some of the mysterious events in the first film, as time moves [[Chronology|non-chronologically]] in the Further.
In the real world, Josh, who is possessed by Parker, ambushes Lorraine and Renai, locking Lorraine in a closet. Renai and the children escape to the basement. Dalton voluntarily enters The Further to help his father. In The Further, Josh, Carl, and Elise try to track Parker down by revisiting Josh in 1986, with the young Josh showing the adult Josh where to find him. In Parker's house, the three witness Parker's mother, Michelle – the woman in the white dress – abusing him for acting like a male; and forcing him to dress and act like a girl. Parker had killed his female victims at the behest of his mother's spirit. Upon finding Michelle, she and Josh fight. Elise saves Josh and appears to destroy Michelle's spirit, which stops the possessed Josh from murdering his family in the real world. Parker's ghost disappears. Carl and Josh escape, only to find Dalton, who leads them back to the living world, allowing Josh to finally regain control of his body. The Lambert family is finally reunited, with Josh and Dalton allowing themselves to once again have their memories suppressed by Carl.
Some time later, Specs and Tucker arrive at the house of a family whose daughter, Allison, is in an unexplained coma. Unbeknownst to them, Elise's spirit enters. She hears a crackling sound and gasps as she sees something standing in the shadows.

LaRose]] as Long-haired fiend * Brooke Peoples as Neighbor Jessica * [[Edwina Findley]] as Front Desk Nurse Hillary * Stephanie Pearson as Dark-haired woman * [[Jorge Pallo]] as Brian * [[Priscilla Garita]] as Natalie * [[Jenna Ortega]] as Annie * Dannay Rodriguez as Allison {{div col end}}
== Production ==
=== Development === {{quote box|align=right|width=35%|quote=It's a direct continuation from the end of the first film, so it's the same characters, same actors coming back. But where the first movie plays like a classic haunted house film, the second one plays more like a domestic thriller with supernatural elements to it.|source=—Wan, on the shift in genre<ref name="LA" />}}
After the financial success of ''[[Insidious (film)|Insidious]]'' In April 2011, discussions for a sequel soon followed. With producer [[Jason Blum]] insisting on the return of director [[James Wan]] and screenwriter [[Leigh Whannell]], a treatment script did not arrive until nearly a year later. "As long as there was a chance that James and Leigh were gonna write the second movie and direct the second movie, I didn't want to do it with someone else," said Blum. "They kept saying they might do it, they might not do it, which was why there's quite a bit of time between the two movies."<ref>{{cite web|last=Nemiroff|first=Perri|title='Insidious Chapter 2' Producer Talks Micro-Budget Horror & 'Amityville: Lost Tapes'|url=http://screenrant.com/insidious-2-interview-jason-blum-amityville-lost-tapes/|publisher=Screen Rant|accessdate=September 11, 2013|date=September 10, 2013}}</ref> On February 2, 2012, it was announced that director [[James Wan]] and screenwriter [[Leigh Whannell]] were in talks to return for the sequel.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kit|first=Borys|title=Horror Hit 'Insidious' to Get Sequel|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/insidious-sequel-rose-byrne-james-wan-leigh-whannell-286790|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=February 2, 2012}}</ref>
While promoting ''[[The Conjuring]]'' (2013) at [[New York Comic Con]] in October 2012, Wan described how he and Whannell were working closely on developing the story and the script for the follow up to ''Insidious'', explaining to [[ShockTilYouDrop.com]], "I think the sequel to ''Insidious'' is kind of my reaction to ''[[Saw (2004 film)|Saw]]'' where for my own reason I wasn't as involved in the sequels, and so I felt with ''Insidious'', think it would be good to shepherd it and keep it more in track to the version I had when I made the first film so that it doesn't detour too far."<ref>{{cite web|last=Douglas|first=Edward|title=NYCC Exclusive: James Wan & Patrick Wilson on Insidious 2|url=http://www.shocktillyoudrop.com/news/170453-nycc-exclusive-james-wan-a-patrick-wilson-on-insidious-2|work=[[Crave Online]]|publisher=[[ShockTilYouDrop.com]]|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=October 14, 2012}}</ref>
The film was titled ''Insidious: Chapter 2'' because it is a direct continuation of the first installment.<ref name="SetVisit">{{cite web|last=Foutch|first=Haleigh|title=25 Things to Know about INSIDIOUS: CHAPTER 2 from Our Set Visit|url=http://collider.com/insidious-chapter-2-set-visit-recap/|publisher=Collider.com|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=May 29, 2013}}</ref> However, the tone of the film was to be more grounded than in the first film, with Wan citing his work on ''The Conjuring'' as an influence to how he and Whannell approached ''Insidious: Chapter 2''.<ref name="LA">{{cite web|last=Day|first=Patrick Kevin|title='Insidious: Chapter 2′ director James Wan on weird, surreal horror|url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/movies/insidious-chapter-2-director-james-wan-on-weird-surreal-horror/|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=May 29, 2013}}</ref> "I pulled things from ''Insidious'' that I applied to ''The Conjuring'', and what I learned from ''The Conjuring'' I applied to ''Insidious 2''," said Wan. "So for me, I feel like it's a cumulative filmmaking experience that I've gathered over the years."<ref>{{cite web|last=Foutch|first=Haleigh|title=James Wan Talks INSIDIOUS: CHAPTER 2, Why He Wanted to Make a Sequel, Taking a Break from Horror, FAST & FURIOUS 7, & the Genre He Wants to Try Next|url=http://collider.com/james-wan-insidious-chapter-2-fast-furious-7-interview/|publisher=Collider.com|accessdate=September 11, 2013|date=September 11, 2013}}</ref>
=== Casting === On November 19, 2012, it was officially announced that [[Patrick Wilson (American actor)|Patrick Wilson]], [[Rose Byrne]], [[Lin Shaye]], and [[Ty Simpkins]] would reprise their roles from the first film.<ref name="HR">{{cite web|last=Kit|first=Borys|title=Patrick Wilson, Rose Byrne Coming Back for 'Insidious' Sequel|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/insidious-sequel-patrick-wilson-rose-393161|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=November 19, 2012}}</ref> The following month, it was announced that [[Barbara Hershey]] would also be returning.<ref>{{cite web|last=Patten|first=Dominic|title=Barbara Hershey Back For 'Insidious Chapter 2′|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/12/barbara-hershey-back-for-insidious-chapter-2/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=December 11, 2012}}</ref> In February 2013, [[Jocelin Donahue]] and Lindsay Seim rounded out the cast as younger versions of Hershey and Shaye's characters, respectively.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kroll|first=Justin|title=Donahue to 'Insidious' role|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/donahue-to-insidious-role-1118065596/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=February 4, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kroll|first=Justin|title=Lindsay Seim Enters 'Insidious 2′ Role|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/lindsay-seim-enters-insidious-2-role-821164/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=February 28, 2013}}</ref> It was also confirmed that the film's screenwriter [[Leigh Whannell]] and actor [[Angus Sampson]] would reprise their roles as Specs and Tucker, respectively. When asked about the return of the two characters, Whannell explained, "There was this hatred that spewed out from fans saying 'I hated those guys! They sucked! They ruined the movie!' so there will probably be a lot of people out there who will be disappointed to hear that the Specs and Tucker characters will be coming back."<ref>{{cite web|title=Exclusive: Writer/Actor Leigh Whannell Confirms Specs and Tucker Characters to Return for Insidious 2|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/52898/exclusive-writeractor-leigh-whannell-confirms-specs-and-tucker-characters-return-insidiou|publisher=Dead Central|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=February 17, 2012}}</ref>
=== Filming === [[Principal photography]] for ''Insidious: Chapter 2'' began on January 15, 2013, in Los Angeles.<ref name="HR" /> Having a slightly higher production budget than its predecessor, the film was captured over the course of 25 shooting days.<ref>{{cite web|title=Insidious Chapter 2 - Q&A with Jason Blum, Leigh Whannell, Patrick Wilson, Lin Shaye, Barbara Hershey and James Wan|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/67172/insidious-chapter-2-qa-jason-blum-leigh-whannell-patrick-wilson-lin-shaye-barbara-hershey|publisher=Dead Central|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=May 30, 2013}}</ref> A bulk of the film was shot at a house in [[Highland Park, Los Angeles]],<ref name="SetVisit" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Insidious: Chapter 2 Filming in Highland Park|url=http://highlandparkgringos.wordpress.com/2013/02/15/insidious-chapter-2-filming-in-highland-park/|work=The Gringos of Highland Park|accessdate=September 16, 2013|date=February 15, 2013}}</ref> which served as the location of Lorraine Lambert's house. Another location used for filming was the former [[Linda Vista Community Hospital]], which was redressed as a hospital setting and used for the construction of interior sets (including recreations of sets from the first film).<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Further Hauntings|journal=[[Film Journal International]]|date=September 2013|volume=116|issue=9|page=12|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]}}</ref><ref name="BD">{{cite web|last=Dickson|first=Evan|title=[Special Report] Getting Answers And Escaping Ghosts On The Set Of 'Insidious Chapter 2′!!|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3235010/special-report-getting-answers-and-escaping-ghosts-on-the-set-of-insidious-chapter-2/|publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=May 29, 2013}}</ref> "I've never shot in Linda Vista," said Wan about the location. "It's kind of funny because Leigh and I have always heard so much about it. For research on the first one [Leigh] came here to do a bit of ghost-hunting. And I think a lot of that inspired us when we needed a hospital set."<ref name="BD" />
=== Music === The [[Film score|musical score]] to ''Insidious: Chapter 2'' is composed by [[Joseph Bishara]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Barkan|first=Jonathan|title=James Wan Confirms Joseph Bishara Back As Composer For 'Insidious Chapter 2'|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3204160/james-wan-confirms-joseph-bishara-back-as-composer-for-insidious-chapter-2/|publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|accessdate=September 5, 2013|date=November 19, 2012}}</ref> who previously collaborated with director [[James Wan]] on the first installment as well as ''The Conjuring''. "Finding the right range and tone for the feeling is an important part," described Bishara on generating tension through sound. "James is very particular with sting placement along with Kirk, our editor on both ''Insidious'' films and ''Conjuring''. Silence can create a listening space, where rather than give you something else to listen to it enables you to hear things."<ref>{{cite web|last=Schweiger|first=Daniel|title=Interview with Joseph Bishara|url=http://www.filmmusicmag.com/?p=11755|publisher=Film Music Magazine|accessdate=September 11, 2013|date=September 10, 2013}}</ref>
A soundtrack album for the film was released digitally on September 15 and in physical forms on October 8, 2013 by Void Recordings.<ref>{{cite web|title='Insidious: Chapter 2′ Soundtrack Details|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2013/09/04/insidious-chapter-2-soundtrack-details/|publisher=Film Music Reporter|accessdate=September 5, 2013|date=September 4, 2013}}</ref> Additional songs featured in the film include:<ref>{{cite web|title=Insidious: Chapter 2 (2013) – Song Credits|url=http://www.soundtrack.net/movie/insidious-chapter-2/|publisher=[[Soundtrack.net]]|accessdate=September 15, 2013}}</ref> * "Waiting For You" by Alan Ett * "[[Piano Sonata No. 2 (Chopin)|Piano Sonata in B-flat Minor, Op. 35, 3rd movement]]" by [[Frédéric Chopin]]
== Distribution ==
=== Marketing === Prior to being officially announced, [[Sony Pictures|Sony Pictures Entertainment]] registered various [[domain names]] on November 28, 2011, for ''Insidious: Chapter 2''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Insidious 2 is in the works according to domain registrations by Sony Pictures|url=http://fusible.com/2011/11/insidious-2-is-in-the-works-according-to-domain-registrations-by-sony-pictures/|publisher=Fusible|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=November 30, 2011}}</ref> On January 30, 2013, the first picture from the set of the film was released via writer [[Leigh Whannell]]'s [[Twitter]] account.<ref>{{cite web|title=First Photo From the Set of Insidious Chapter 2|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=99541|work=[[CraveOnline]]|publisher=Comingsoon.net|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=January 30, 2013}}</ref> Additional behind-the-scenes photos from the set of the film were released the following month.<ref>{{cite web|last=Billington|first=Alex|title=First Look: Candles and The Kid in James Wan's 'Insidious: Chapter 2'|url=http://www.firstshowing.net/2013/first-look-candles-the-kid-in-james-wans-insidious-chapter-2/|publisher=FirstShowing.net|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=February 1, 2013}}</ref> In April 2013, the first promotional poster for the film went on display at [[CinemaCon]] in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Weintraub|first=Steve|title=First Posters for Spike Lee's OLDBOY and James Wan's INSIDIOUS: CHAPTER 2|url=http://collider.com/oldboy-poster-spike-lee-insidious-cahpter-2-poster/|publisher=Collider.com|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=April 14, 2013}}</ref> The first theatrical trailer for the film was screened to a live audience on location at the Linda Vista Community Hospital on June 4, 2013, with an online release the following day.<ref>{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Justin|title=The Further Awaits In Debut INSIDIOUS CHAPTER 2 Trailer!|url=http://iconsoffright.com/2013/06/05/the-further-awaits-in-debut-insidious-chapter-2-trailer/|publisher=Icons of Fright|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=June 5, 2013}}</ref> On August 10, 2013, it was announced at the convention Scare L.A by producer Jason Blum and Universal's creative director John Murdy, that a maze attraction entitled "Insidious: Into the Further" will be featured at the 2013 [[Halloween Horror Nights]] at [[Universal Studios Hollywood]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Brigante|first=Ricky|title=Insidious: Into the Further haunted house announced for Halloween Horror Nights 2013 at Universal Studios Hollywood|url=http://www.insidethemagic.net/2013/08/insidious-into-the-further-haunted-house-announced-for-halloween-horror-nights-2013-at-universal-studios-hollywood/|publisher=Inside the Magic|accessdate=August 13, 2013|date=August 10, 2013}}</ref>
=== Theatrical release === While originally intended to be released on August 30, 2013,<ref name="HR" /> ''Insidious: Chapter 2'' was rescheduled for a September 20 release date.<ref>{{cite web|title=Things Get 'Insidious' This September!|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3221355/things-get-insidious-this-september/|publisher=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=March 1, 2013}}</ref> The film's release date was later moved again to September 13, 2013.<ref name="release">{{cite web|last=Schaefer|first=Sandy|title=New Release Dates for 'Kung Fu Panda 3′, 'Insidious 2′, 'I, Frankenstein' and 'Pompeii'|url=http://screenrant.com/kung-fu-panda-3-insidious-2-i-frankenstein-pompeii-release-date/|publisher=Screen Rant|accessdate=June 5, 2013|date=May 2013}}</ref>
On the night prior to its theatrical wide release, the film was shown in select theatres as part of a double feature with the [[Insidious (film)|first installment]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Trumbore|first=Dave|title=INSIDIOUS and INSIDIOUS: CHAPTER 2 Double Feature Screening on Thursday, September 12th|url=http://collider.com/insidious-double-feature/|publisher=Collider.com|accessdate=August 28, 2013|date=August 28, 2013}}</ref> A [[red carpet]] [[Film premiere|premiere]] for the film was held in [[Los Angeles]] on September 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kirby|first=Iona|title=A rose for a Rose! Miss Byrne is stunning in a flower print pink dress which reveals her slim legs at Insidious: Chapter 2 premiere|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2417255/Rose-Byrne-stunning-flower-print-pink-dress-reveals-slim-legs-Insidious-Chapter-2-premiere.html?ito=feeds-newsxml|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=September 11, 2013|date=September 11, 2013}}</ref>
== Release ==
=== Box office === Preliminary reports had the film tracking for a $32–$35 million debut in North America.<ref>{{cite web|last=Subers|first=Ray|title=Forecast: 'Insidious 2' Poised to Possess Audiences on Friday The 13th|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3729&p=.htm|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDB]]|accessdate=September 13, 2013|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kaufman|first=Amy|title='Insidious: Chapter 2' to spook 'The Family' at box office|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-box-office-insidious-family-20130911,0,5050381.story|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|accessdate=September 13, 2013|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref> The film earned $1.5 million from its Thursday night showings,<ref>{{cite web|last=Lang|first=Brent|title='Insidious: Chapter 2′ Racks Up $1.5M at Thursday Box Office|url=http://www.thewrap.com/insidious-chapter-2-racks-up-1-5m-at-thursday-box-office/|publisher=[[The Wrap]]|accessdate=September 13, 2013|date=September 13, 2013}}</ref> and reached a $20 million Friday total, making it the biggest opening day in September box office history.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title=Friday Box Office: 'Insidious Chapter 2' Scares Up $20m on Friday the 13th|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2013/09/14/friday-box-office-insidious-2-scares-up-20m-on-friday-the-13th/|work=[[Forbes]]|publisher=Forbes Publishing|accessdate=September 14, 2013|date=September 14, 2013}}</ref> It went on to be the number one film during its opening weekend, taking $41 million at the box office.<ref>{{cite web|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Box Office: 'Insidious 2' Nabs $41 Million, No. 2 September Debut of All Time|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-insidious-2-nabs-629608|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=September 27, 2013|date=September 15, 2013}}</ref> The film grossed a worldwide total of $161,919,318 against a budget of $5 million.<ref name="BOM">{{cite web|title=Insidious Chapter 2 (2013)|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=insidious2.htm|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[Internet Movie Database|IMDb]]|accessdate=December 24, 2013}}</ref>
=== Critical response === Review aggregate [[Rotten Tomatoes]] sampled 111 reviews and judged 39% of the reviews to be positive. The site's consensus reads: "''Insidious: Chapter 2'' is decidedly short on the tension and surprises that made its predecessor so chilling."<ref>{{cite web|title=Insidious: Chapter 2 (2013)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/insidious_chapter_2/|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Flixster]]|accessdate=September 15, 2013}}</ref> [[Metacritic]], another review aggregator, assigned the film a weighted average score of 40 out of 100 based on 30 reviews from mainstream critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web|title=Insidious: Chapter 2|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/insidious-chapter-2|work=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=September 15, 2013}}</ref>
[[Robbie Collin]] of ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'' gave the film a positive review, stating that "the scares are mostly very scary indeed, and that means the film does its job."<ref>{{cite web|last=Collin|first=Robbie|title=Insidious: Chapter 2, review|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmreviews/10304051/Insidious-Chapter-2-review.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|accessdate=September 12, 2013|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref> Scott Foundas of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' praised the "artfully eerie" cinematography work of [[John R. Leonetti]] and the "pervasively unsettling atmosphere" constructed by sound designer and editor Joe Dzuban. Foundas further wrote that "where so many sequels seem like mere remakes of their predecessors, with bigger budgets and less imagination, ''Insidious: Chapter 2'' feels like a genuine continuation of characters we enjoyed getting to know the first time around, and wouldn't at all mind returning to again."<ref>{{cite web|author=Scott Foundas |url=https://variety.com/2013/film/reviews/film-review-insidious-chapter-2-1200607706/ |title='Insidious: Chapter 2′ Review: James Wan's Pleasurable Sequel |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=2013-09-12 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> Conversely, Robert Abele of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' commented, "After the pleasurable free fall into old-fashioned nightmare artistry that was last summer's ''The Conjuring'', this busy-yet-dull sequel feels like Wan robotically flexing his manipulation of fright-film signposts, an exercise more silly than sinister."<ref>{{cite web|last=Abele|first=Robert|title=Review: 'Insidious: Chapter 2' adds nothing to the story|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-insidious-2-review,0,4147571.story?|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|accessdate=September 12, 2013|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref> Justin Lowe of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' wrote, "Setting aside the movie's tediously lame dialogue, self-conscious performances and frequently predictable scares, the narrative's compulsively shifting chronology intermittently manages to engage, although it does little to obscure the distracting shortcomings of both plot and character development."<ref>{{cite web|last=Lowe|first=Justin|title=Insidious: Chapter 2: Film Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/insidious-chapter-2/review/628279|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=September 12, 2013|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref>
=== Home media === The film was released on Blu-ray and DVD on December 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=12512 |title=Insidious: Chapter 2 Blu-ray |publisher=Blu-ray.com |date= |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref>
== Prequel == {{main|Insidious: Chapter 3}}
On September 16, 2013, a third film in the series was announced with [[Leigh Whannell]] signed on to return as writer while [[Jason Blum]] and [[Oren Peli]] are also set to produce.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chitwood|first=Adam|title=INSIDIOUS: CHAPTER THREE Moving Forward; Leigh Whannell Returning to Write the Script|url=http://collider.com/insidious-3-sequel-leigh-whannell/|publisher=Collider.com|accessdate=September 16, 2013|date=September 16, 2013}}</ref> When asked about returning for another sequel, actor [[Patrick Wilson (American actor)|Patrick Wilson]] went on to say that he "[doesn't] know where else it could go", and that "[Josh Lambert has] been through the wringer, and I think the movie sets it up well at the end ... And that's great, that's how it should end."<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Nigel M.|title=Patrick Wilson On Why There Won't Be an 'Insidious 3' and His Love for 'Conjuring' Director James Wan|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/patrick-wilson-on-why-there-wont-be-an-insidious-3-and-his-love-for-director-james-wan?page=2#articleHeaderPanel|work=[[Indiewire]]|accessdate=September 16, 2013|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref> On March 11, 2014, it was reported that the third film wouldn't focus on the Lambert family, but would focus on a new family and story, that it wouldn't connect to the last teaser scene in the second film, and that Whannell and Sampson wouldn't return as ghost hunters Specs and Tucker. On May 7, 2014, Wan tweeted that Whannell would be directing the third film, which would mark his directorial debut.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/creepypuppet/status/464105691834093568?p=v |title=James Wan on Twitter: "I'm truly honored & excited to b passing the torch onto my great bud @LWhannell, who'll make his directorial debut w #INSIDIOUS 3 @blumhouse" |publisher=Twitter.com |date=2014-05-07 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> [[Stefanie Scott]] and [[Dermot Mulroney]] starred in the film.<ref>{{cite news|title=Horror Sequel 'Insidious: Chapter 3′ Scares Up 'Jem,' 'A.N.T. Farm' Star Stefanie Scott|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/06/stefanie-scott-insidious-chapter-3-jem-and-the-holograms/|accessdate=12 June 2014|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=11 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hollywoodreporter.com/v/MoviesNews/DermotMulroneyStarIn3/|title=Dermot Mulroney to Star in 'Insidious: Chapter 3'|last=Kit|first=Borys|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 25, 2014|accessdate=June 25, 2014}}</ref> [[Focus Features]] and [[Stage 6 Films]] released the follow-up on June 5, 2015.
==See also== * [[List of ghost films]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Circus performers]]; added [[Category:Soviet circus performers]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[Image:Irina Bugrimova Postal card Russia 2010.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The [[postal card]] issued to commemorate the 100th birth anniversary of Irina Bugrimova. <small>The [[Russian Post]], 2010.</small>]] '''Irina Bugrimova''' (1910–2001) was the first female [[Lion taming|lion tamer]] in the [[Soviet Union]]. Called a "[[circus]] legend" by sources such as the [[BBC]],<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/monitoring/media_reports/1182020.stm |title=Russia's lion queen dies |date=February 21, 2001 |publisher=[[BBC]] }}</ref> Bugrimova was the first woman in Russia and the then-Soviet Union to work with lions, [[tigers]], and [[ligers]] in a variety of performing acts,<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/03/18/world/irina-bugrimova-90-an-enchanter-of-big-cats.html |title=Irina Bugrimova, 90, an Enchanter of Big Cats |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |last=Martin |first=Douglas |date=March 18, 2001 }}</ref> and trained more than 70 big cats during her career.<ref name="Telegraph">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1325425/Irina-Bugrimova.html |title=Irina Bugrimova |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=March 8, 2001}}</ref>
==Biography== Irina Nikolajewna Bugrimova was born in [[Kharkiv]], [[Russian Empire]] (now [[Ukraine]]) on March 13, 1910.<ref name="NYT"/> The daughter of a [[veterinarian]] and a [[ballet dancer]], she excelled in athletics as a child, including as a champion [[speed skater]].<ref name="NYT"/> She eventually parlayed her talent into a career as a [[motorcyclist]] and gymnast at circuses, among other things.<ref name="BBC"/>
She died in [[Moscow]].
==Animal training== In 1929, Bugrimova transferred to the [[Moscow State Circus]], and it was there she met the animal trainers Nikolaj Gladilstchikow and Boris Eder, who taught her the practice.<ref name="Telegraph"/> She made her debut ten years later in 1939, and designed many of her own tricks, such as lions [[tightrope walking]], acts involving motorcycles, and a giant swing which she would leap from with a cat. In one stunt, a lion would run in front of her motorcycle as if in fear, while another would jump onto the back of her seat to ride along. She flirted with danger by swinging on a giant swing with a lion. At the end of the routine the two jumped off the swing together and she fed the animal a piece of meat with her teeth. Her act ended with the lions laying down as she cavorted on a carpet of cats. Later she worked with the Circus Humberto in [[Czechoslovakia]] and the [[East German]] Circus.<ref name="NYT"/>
Bugrimova performed in circuses well into her 60s,<ref name="BBC"/><ref name="Telegraph"/> and was decorated several times by the Soviet state.<ref name="BBC"/> Today there is also an avenue named in her honor in her hometown of Kharkiv, in front of the city's circus.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://maps.google.com/maps/place?q=Kharkiv,+Kharkivs'ka,+Ukraine+circus&hl=en&cid=12706666251370739799 |title=ХАРЬКОВСКИЙ ГОСУДАРСТВЕННЫЙ ЦИРК |work=[[Google Maps]] }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Mabel Stark]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bugrimova, Irina}} [[Category:Soviet circus performers]] [[Category:Ukrainian women]] [[Category:1910 births]] [[Category:2001 deaths]] [[Category:Animal trainers]] [[Category:Burials in Troyekurovskoye Cemetery]]
